instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Hi, I have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board with liquid damage around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and the backlight stuff also.
I've narrowed it down to <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> not creating <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and that's due to <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> missing.

So, checking around PMIC, I could see that <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> is good, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> is good, <SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL> is good.
<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL> is high.
On this board, <RESISTOR>R7828</RESISTOR> is the one present.

What should I check next ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage (without battery)?
USB-C ports switch to 20V?
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
PPBUS is 13.02V
And yeah I should maybe have started there, but no issue with the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> stuff, of course. 20V from charger, which also implies <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is indeed present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at L7670/90.
Also check at all PCH/CPU coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Diode mode and resistance to ground:
L7670: 0.407V 900Ohms
L7690: 0.353V 780Ohms

PPVCCGT: 0.0023V 4.6Ohms
PPVCCCPU: 0.0043V 9Ohms
PPVCCSA: 0.0066V  13.37Ohms
PPVCCPCH: 0.0652V 130Ohms
PPVCCIO: 0.0531V 106Ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Check solders, traces and all the components around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>.
Change the chip, just in case.
Check diode mode at <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Diode mode at <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 0.410V, so there's no short.
Traces, solders and probe points look okay, and I have tested continuity for the few ones I had a small doubt, they are all good.
I guess I'll try to replace the chip, just in case as you said, but I can't see how it can be the issue when the enable signal is low (and not shorted to ground)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Yeah that's what I thought too. I don't have any right now. I'll put this aside for now and report back later once I get some and replaced it.
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Hi,
So I finally received my parts. <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> replaced, but <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> is still low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message: Both resistors are good, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Then bad <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or its solders...
No pulse at all at  <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
No, no pulse. It goes from floating state to 0V when I connect charger and that's it. And I do get the LDOs (<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL>) with the new chip too.
So, you suggest that I try again with another <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message:
Do you know what's required as input on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> for it to make <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> high ?
<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> is PGD, so does that mean that it needs VSD to be good ? Or VSA, VSB, VSC, VSD all need to be good ?
I assume VSx stands for Voltage Sense, and PGx stands for Power Good, so I'd expect PGD to turn on if VSD is good, but maybe there's additional logic that requires other voltage sense to also be good so that power rails turn on in sequence ?

What about the STANDBY# pin of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> ? Can it have an effect on <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not starting
threads.message: Seems that PMIC gets all required signal to enable S5 state.
